questions.text: A 28-year-old African American male presents with nephrotic syndrome and progressive renal failure. Renal biopsy reveals focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following genetic polymorphisms is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) APOL1 polymorphism

 

Option D:

 

APOL1 gene variants are strongly associated with FSGS and other forms of non-diabetic kidney disease in African Americans.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. & B. NPHS1 and NPHS2: Mutations are associated with congenital nephrotic syndrome, not FSGS in adults.

 

Option C. TRPC6 mutations: Can cause FSGS, but they are less common than APOL1 variants in African Americans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

APOL1 gene variants are a significant risk factor for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and other forms of non-diabetic kidney disease in individuals of African descent.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous nephropathy

 

Option C:

 

Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome in adults, particularly in Caucasian populations. Here's a brief explanation for the

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: This is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, but less frequent in adults.

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS can cause nephrotic syndrome, but it's less common than membranous nephropathy in adults.

 

Option D. Diabetic nephropathy: This is a leading cause of chronic kidney disease, but it typically presents with proteinuria in the absence of the full-blown nephrotic syndrome (edema, hyperlipidemia, hypoalbuminemia).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, especially in Caucasian populations.

choices.text: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
Minimal change disease

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese woman with controlled hypertension has nephrotic-range proteinuria and mild edema. Renal biopsy reveals segmental scarring in 60% of glomeruli, mainly at the corticomedullary junction. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

 

Option A:

 

FSGS: The biopsy finding of segmental scarring in a subset of glomeruli, especially in the corticomedullary junction, is characteristic of FSGS. Additionally, the patient's obesity is a known risk factor for FSGS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypertensive nephrosclerosis: While the patient has hypertension, the biopsy findings do not fit the typical pattern of nephrosclerosis (arteriolosclerosis and global glomerulosclerosis).

 

Option C. Minimal change disease: This would usually present with less severe proteinuria and no glomerular scarring on biopsy.

 

Option D. Crescentic glomerulonephritis: This is a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis with crescents (proliferations of cells) on biopsy, not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by segmental scarring in a subset of glomeruli, often associated with obesity.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypokalemia

 

Option D:

 

PSGN is not typically associated with hypokalemia (low potassium).

 

Explanation:

 

Options A, B & C: These are classic features of PSGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) typically presents with hematuria, proteinuria and hypertension, but not hypokalemia. The usual timeframe for PSGN development after impetigo is 2-6 weeks.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with hematuria and edema, three weeks after a confirmed case of impetigo. Which of the following is the most appropriate time frame for the development of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) following impetigo?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2-6 weeks

 

Option B:

 

The typical time frame for the development of PSGN after impetigo is 2-6 weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1-3 weeks: This time frame is too short for PSGN to develop after a streptococcal infection like impetigo.

 

Option C. 3-8 weeks: While PSGN can occasionally present slightly later, the most typical window is within the first 2-6 weeks.

 

Option D. 2-6 days: This time frame is far too short. PSGN takes weeks, not days, to manifest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune-mediated complication that can occur after a streptococcal infection. The classic presentation includes hematuria (blood in the urine), edema (swelling) and hypertension. The most common time frame for the development of PSGN following a streptococcal infection is 2-6 weeks. Recognizing this typical time frame is crucial for timely diagnosis and management of PSGN.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with proteinuria, edema and a normal serum creatinine. Renal biopsy reveals Thickened basement membranes with diffuse sub-epithelial immune deposit. Which of the following complications is she at increased risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Renal vein thrombosis

 

Option B:

 

Lupus nephritis class V, like idiopathic membranous nephropathy, is associated with an increased risk of thrombotic events, particularly renal vein thrombosis. The membranous changes in the glomerular basement membrane can disrupt blood flow and increase the risk of clot formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute kidney injury: While possible in SLE, it's less common with class V lupus nephritis, which typically has a more insidious onset.

 

Option C. Nephritic syndrome: This is characterized by hematuria and hypertension, which are not prominent features of class V lupus nephritis.

 

Option D. Hypocomplementemia: While common in other classes of lupus nephritis, it's not always present in class V, which is often associated with normal complement levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus nephritis class V (membranous lupus nephritis) carries an increased risk of renal vein thrombosis.

choices.text: Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane
Subepithelial immune complex deposits

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with hemoptysis (coughing up blood), shortness of breath and hematuria. His serum creatinine is elevated. A renal biopsy is taken and immunofluorescence is shown below. Given the likely diagnosis, what would be the immunofluorescence findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane

 

Option B:

 

Linear IgG deposits on immunofluorescence are a hallmark of anti-GBM disease, the underlying cause of Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mesangial cell proliferation: Is seen in IgA nephropathy and other conditions.

 

Option C. Subepithelial immune complex deposits: Are characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

 

Option D. Mesangial IgA deposits: Are seen in IgA nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence are characteristic of Goodpasture syndrome (anti-GBM disease).

choices.text: Children under 5 years old

questions.text: Which of the following demographic groups is MOST likely to be affected by IgA nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Young men

 

Option B:

 

IgA nephropathy has a peak incidence in the second and third decades of life, and it is more common in men than women.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Elderly women: IgA nephropathy is less common in elderly individuals and slightly more common in men than women.

 

Option C. Children under 5 years old: While IgA nephropathy can occur in children, it is more typically diagnosed in adolescents and young adults.

 

Option D. African American individuals: IgA nephropathy is less prevalent in individuals of African descent compared to those of Caucasian or Asian descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, primarily affects young men, particularly those in their teens to late 30s. While it can affect individuals of any age, gender or race, certain demographic factors increase the risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypocomplementemia

 

Option D:

 

AAV is characterized by a pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, meaning there are few immune deposits in the glomerulus. Complement levels are typically normal or even elevated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palpable purpura: Is a common skin manifestation of AAV.

 

Option B. Mononeuritis multiplex: (asymmetric peripheral neuropathy) is also a classic finding.

 

Option C: Hematuria and proteinuria: Are common due to glomerulonephritis

 

Educational Objective:

 

ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) does not typically present with hypocomplementemia.

questions.text: What percentage of Alport syndrome cases are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15%

 

Option B:

 

Approximately 15% of Alport syndrome cases are caused by mutations in both copies of the COL4A3 or COL4A4 gene, which are located on non-sex chromosomes. This is known as autosomal recessive inheritance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 5%: This is the approximate percentage for the less common autosomal dominant form.

 

Option C. 50%: This is the probability of inheritance for each child if one parent has the X-linked dominant form.

 

Option D. 85%: This is the approximate percentage for the most common X-linked dominant form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder primarily affecting the kidneys, hearing, and vision. While most cases (around 80-85%) are inherited in an X-linked pattern, approximately 15% of cases are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that both parents must carry a mutated gene for their child to be affected

choices.text: Thin basement membrane nephropathy (TBMN)
Minimal change disease (MCD)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent hematuria and a family history of kidney disease, on further questioning he has difficulty in hearing since childhood. A renal biopsy reveals thin glomerular basement membranes (GBMs) on electron microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alport syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Thin GBM is an early and characteristic finding in young Alport syndrome patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IgA nephropathy: Presents with mesangial IgA deposits.

 

Option B. Thin basement membrane nephropathy (TBMN): This is a benign condition with persistent thin GBM, but no progression to multilamellation or other Alport features.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease (MCD): Does not cause thinning of the GBM.

 

Educational objective:

 

  •  Alport syndrome is primarily inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern (approximately 85%), but 15% of cases follow an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • Thin glomerular basement membranes (GBMs) on electron microscopy, combined with recurrent hematuria and a family history of kidney disease and hearing loss, are suggestive of Alport syndrome.

choices.text: Benign familial hematuria

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with asymptomatic microscopic hematuria and a family history of similar findings. Renal function is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Benign familial hematuria

 

Option C:

 

TBMN, aka Benign familial hematuria, is a benign condition characterized by persistent or recurrent microscopic hematuria, often with a family history of similar findings. Renal function remains normal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alport syndrome: Usually has proteinuria and progressive kidney disease.

 

Option B. IgA nephropathy: Presents with episodic gross hematuria, often after infections.

 

Option D. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): Occurs after streptococcal infection, with edema and hypertension

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benign familial hematuria (thin basement membrane nephropathy) is the most likely diagnosis in a child with asymptomatic microscopic hematuria and a positive family history. It is a benign condition with normal renal function.

choices.text: Acute kidney injury
All of the above

questions.text: A patient with nephrotic syndrome is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is a hypercoagulable state, predisposing to thromboembolic events. Loss of immunoglobulins in the urine increases infection risk. Also, the underlying kidney disease can progress to AKI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thromboembolism: Nephrotic syndrome leads to the loss of proteins involved in blood clotting, increasing the risk of blood clots.

 

Option B. Infection: Loss of immunoglobulins (antibodies) in the urine makes individuals more susceptible to infections.

 

Option C. Acute kidney injury: The underlying kidney disease causing nephrotic syndrome can worsen, leading to acute kidney injury

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome increases the risk of blood clots, infections, and kidney failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperkalemia

 

Option D:

 

Hyperkalemia is not a characteristic finding in nephrotic syndrome. In fact, hypokalemia can occur due to diuretic use or other factors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Proteinuria > 3.5 g/day: This is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome. The excessive loss of protein in the urine is a defining characteristic.

 

Option B. Hypoalbuminemia: This occurs due to the significant loss of albumin (a protein) in the urine, leading to low albumin levels in the blood.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: The liver tries to compensate for the protein loss by increasing the production of lipids (fats), leading to high levels of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by a constellation of findings, including heavy proteinuria, low albumin levels, and elevated lipids. Hyperkalemia (high potassium) is not typically associated with nephrotic syndrome; in fact, hypokalemia (low potassium) is more common due to urinary losses.

choices.text: Sub-endothelial immune complex deposits
Mesangial electron-dense deposits
Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane
Effacement of podocyte foot processes

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with generalized edema, massive proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia. Given the likely diagnosis, what would be electron microscopic findings would be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Effacement of podocyte foot processes

 

Option D:

 

The clinical presentation of generalized edema, massive proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia is consistent with nephrotic syndrome. In children, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome is minimal change disease. The hallmark of MCD on electron microscopy is the effacement of podocyte foot processes, which are essential for the glomerular filtration barrier.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option A. Sub-endothelial immune complex deposits: This is typically seen in lupus nephritis and other immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis.

 

Option B. Mesangial electron-dense deposits: This is characteristic of IgA nephropathy.

 

Option C. Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane: This is seen in thin basement membrane nephropathy, a benign condition with minimal proteinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests minimal change disease (MCD), which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. The hallmark electron microscopic finding in MCD is the effacement (flattening or fusion) of podocyte foot processes. These foot processes are crucial for the filtration barrier in the glomerulus and their damage leads to the massive proteinuria seen in nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: In children diagnosed with minimal change disease (MCD), what percentage is expected to achieve spontaneous remission without specific treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 10%

 

Option A:

 

While spontaneous remission can occur in children with MCD, it's relatively uncommon. Approximately 30% of children may experience spontaneous remission without requiring corticosteroid therapy. The majority of children with MCD respond well to corticosteroids, with a remission rate of around 90-95%.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 30%, Option C. 50% & Option D. 75%: These percentages are too high. While spontaneous remission can happen in MCD, it's not the norm. Most children require treatment with corticosteroids to achieve remission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. The hallmark of MCD on electron microscopy is the effacement of podocyte foot processes. Spontaneous remission occurs in a minority of children with MCD (approximately 10%), while the majority respond well to corticosteroid therapy.

choices.text: Weight loss and blood pressure control

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese man with a history of hypertension presents with proteinuria, edema and hypoalbuminemia. Renal biopsy reveals focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following would be the LEAST appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Corticosteroids

 

Option C:

 

This patient's FSGS is likely secondary to obesity and hypertension. Secondary FSGS generally does not respond to immunosuppression like corticosteroids.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A, B & D:  These are all appropriate initial interventions for secondary FSGS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary FSGS, often due to obesity and hypertension, usually doesn't respond to corticosteroids. Treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause and using renoprotective agents (ACEi/ARBs).

choices.text: Continue current therapy and monitor closely.
Add a corticosteroid.
Consider renal biopsy.

questions.text: A patient with obesity-related FSGS is started on a weight loss program and an ACE inhibitor. After 6 months, their proteinuria has significantly decreased. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue current therapy and monitor closely.

 

Option A:

 

In secondary FSGS, treating the underlying cause (obesity) and using renoprotective agents (ACE inhibitors) can lead to remission. If the response is good, no further intervention is needed at this time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Add a corticosteroid: Corticosteroids are typically used for other forms of FSGS, not primarily obesity-related. Adding them unnecessarily could expose the patient to potential side effects without a clear benefit.

 

Option C. Consider renal biopsy: A renal biopsy is typically performed at the initial diagnosis to confirm FSGS and exclude other causes. If the patient is responding well to therapy, a repeat biopsy is usually not indicated.

 

Option D. Initiate dialysis: Dialysis is indicated in cases of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) when the kidneys are no longer functioning adequately. This patient is responding to therapy and does not show signs of ESRD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 If a patient with obesity-related FSGS responds well to initial therapy (weight loss and ACEi/ARB), continued monitoring is usually sufficient. Further intervention isn't immediately necessary.

choices.text: MPGN type I
MPGN type II
MPGN type III

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with “tram-track” appearance of renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) MPGN type I

 

Option A:

 

The "tram-track" appearance is due to mesangial interposition between the GBM and endothelial cells, a characteristic finding in MPGN type I.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. MPGN type II:  Shows dense deposits within the GBM, not the tram-track appearance.

 

Option C. MPGN type III:  Is similar to type I but with less prominent mesangial interposition.

 

Option D. Alport syndrome: Shows splitting and lamellation of the GBM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "tram-track" appearance on renal biopsy is a hallmark of MPGN type I due to the characteristic mesangial interposition. This distinctive finding helps differentiate MPGN type I from other glomerular diseases.

choices.text: The majority of patients will experience spontaneous remission within 5 years.
Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis.
Approximately 50% of patients will develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD) within 10 years.
Early treatment with corticosteroids can prevent progression to ESRD in most cases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is newly diagnosed with idiopathic membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I. Which of the following statements regarding their prognosis is MOST accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Approximately 50% of patients will develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD) within 10 years.

 

Option C:

 

MPGN type I is a progressive disease, and studies have shown that about 50% of patients will develop ESRD within 10 years of diagnosis. This underscores the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate management to slow disease progression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The majority of patients will experience spontaneous remission within 5 years:  Spontaneous remission is rare in MPGN type I.

 

Option B. Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis:  Renal function typically declines over time, with 90% of patients developing renal insufficiency within 20 years.

 

Option D. Early treatment with corticosteroids can prevent progression to ESRD in most cases:  While corticosteroids may be beneficial in some cases, they do not guarantee prevention of ESRD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MPGN type I is a progressive disease with a poor prognosis. Approximately half of the patients progress to ESRD within 10 years, emphasizing the need for early diagnosis and management to potentially slow disease progression. While treatments like corticosteroids may be used, they do not guarantee prevention of ESRD.

choices.text: The risk is lower than in patients with other causes of ESRD.
The risk is the same as in patients with other causes of ESRD.
The risk is higher than in patients with other causes of ESRD.
There is no association between analgesic nephropathy and urothelial malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the risk of urothelial malignancy in patients with analgesic nephropathy-related ESRD is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The risk is higher than in patients with other causes of ESRD.

 

Option C:

 

Studies have shown that patients with ESRD due to analgesic nephropathy have a significantly higher risk of developing urothelial malignancies compared to patients with ESRD from other causes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The risk is lower than in patients with other causes of ESRD: This is incorrect. The association between analgesic nephropathy and urothelial malignancy increases the risk compared to other ESRD causes.

 

Option B. The risk is the same as in patients with other causes of ESRD: While patients with ESRD generally have a higher risk of certain malignancies, the risk of urothelial malignancy is specifically elevated in those with analgesic nephropathy.

 

Option D. There is no association between analgesic nephropathy and urothelial malignancy: Extensive research has established a clear link between prolonged analgesic use, analgesic nephropathy, and the increased risk of developing urothelial cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) caused by analgesic nephropathy are at an increased risk of developing urothelial malignancies (cancers of the urinary tract) compared to individuals with ESRD from other causes.
